messageBody:
tinyallen wrote:
> How about using the actual native's name, as well as
> pronunciation? For example, what we Americans call
> Munich is (AFAIK) "Myuunchen" to a local German
> speaker. I have had international friends who wondered
> why Americans (and the British) couldn't say the names
> of a few cities.

Which opens the subject that QS is for better or worse quite
tightly bound to the particular sound inventory, especially
vowel inventory, of mid 20th-century English, and not easily
adapted or expanded to other languages or even to ongoing
sound changes in English, where new vowel distinctions arise
or old ones disappear.

To a German "myuunchen" with 17+40 and or "myoonchen" with
17+39 or "muinchen" with 39+26 would all be deficient ways
of representing the actual sound anyway, without going into
how the consonant written "ch" should be represented, which
actually occurs in some English speakers pronunciation of
"huge". 19+17 is an unwieldy combo, and I find myself
wanting to write 19+26+40, or to construct the letter which
relates to #17 as #20 to #18 -- essentially Read's loCH
letter turned upside-down.

For an earlier post on these matters see
<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/message/855>

On 25.4.2007 pgabhart wrote:
> I have seen it suggested that we should spell as if the
> word were emphasized rather than spelling in accordance
> with the slovenly way we frequently pronounce words in the
> middle of a sentence.

It is unfair to normal fast speech -- not to mention the
Slovenes :-) -- to use such wording. From a phoneticians
point of view fast-speech reductions are not only completely
natural, but also necessary to achieve fast speech at all.
Compare how someone...who...has...difficulty...articulating
is usually depicted by actors! A person who enunciated
maximally 'clear' all the time in normal conversation would
be quite irritating for sure.

This said the principle to base the spelling of words on how
they are enunciated in isolation is a good one, since else
the spelling of words would have to vary not only according
to whose dialect it represented, but also according to how
fast they were supposed to speak, since of course both the
amount and patterns of reduction increases the faster we
speak. Speakers actually have a mental image of how words
are ideally enunciated, e.g. as when reading a word list,
which they employ as a standard of comparison when
interpreting actual speech at various speeds, even though
they seldom actually use that ideal pronunciation, and it
has always been that ideal pronunciation people have tried
to represent in writing.

In short it would be as inefficient to always enunciate
maximally 'clear' in speech, as to represent normal fast
speech in writing, and there is no reason for bad-
mouthing either.
--


/BP 8^)>
